Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Endovenous Laser Ablation and Radiofrequency Ablation for Great Saphenous Vein Incompetence

Trial_Design.evidence: A single-centre, double-blind, three-arm, superiority randomised controlled trial

Participants.evidence: Adult patients with symptomatic great saphenous vein (GSV) incompetence were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive EVLA, dRFA, or iRFA

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the efficacy of EVLA with direct RFA (dRFA) and indirect RFA (iRFA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was GSV occlusion rate at 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using stratified block randomisation, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 451 patients were randomised, with 450 receiving treatment

Result_Outcome.evidence: occlusion rates of 75.0% (95% CI 68.0 to 82.0) for EVLA, 59.9% (52.1 to 67.7) for dRFA, and 81.3% (75.1 to 87.6) for iRFA.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were more frequent in the EVLA group, particularly pain.
